div3.head: PROPOSITION 29.
div3.p: In equal circles equal circumferences are subtended by equal straight lines.
Let ABC, DEF be equal circles, and in them let equal circumferences BGC, EHF be cut off; and let the straight lines BC, EF be joined; I say that BC is equal to EF.
For let the centres of the circles be taken, and let them be K, L; let BK, KC, EL, LF be joined.
Now, since the circumference BGC is equal to the circumference EHF, the angle BKC is also equal to the angle ELF. [III. 27]

And, since the circles ABC, DEF are equal, the radii are also equal; therefore the two sides BK, KC are equal to the two sides EL, LF; and they contain equal angles; therefore the base BC is equal to the base EF. [I. 4]
